channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for NY

item.title: Report E-2024010348
item.description:
Report E-2024010348

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-22T15:12:13+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-11
  • City: TONAWANDA
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On January 11, 2024, four (4) one-gallon bottles of sodium hydroxide were crushed in transit and released approximately less than one (<1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from EnviroServe (ES) to remediate the impacted site. ES personnel deployed soda ash and absorbent pads to the sodium hydroxide-impacted trailer interior and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents and impacted cardboard were collected and containerized into one (1) 35-gallon drum. An additional 35-gallon drum was used to contain the damaged 1-gallon jugs and both were set aside for terminal disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024010239
item.description:
Report E-2024010239

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-18T15:13:34+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-09
  • City: TROY
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On January 9, 2024, one (1) 5-gallon box of UN1824 fell in transit and released approximately four (4) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Miller Environmental Group (MEG) to remediate the impacted site. MEG personnel deployed granular absorbents, neutralizer and absorbent pads to the sodium hydroxide solution-impacted trailer interior and impacted pallets. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum for terminal disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024010383
item.description:
Report E-2024010383

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-24T15:11:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-19
  • City: NEWBURGH
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: A DUIE PYLE INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On December 19, 2023, at 0711 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by A Duie Pile personnel in Newburgh, NY regarding the release of an unknown amount of various products due to a multiple vehicle accident (The speed of the vehicle is unknown). Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release of multiple materials which included KEM AQUAÂ® 400 Waterborne Enamel (UN1263, 3, III), Polane Plus Enamel (Part A) (UN1263, 3, III), and a Flammable Liquid, Corrosive, n.o.s. (UN1263, 3, II). Contractors were unable to assess approximately how much of each were released due to the materials mixing with each other. Contractors were able to clean the release with absorbents and the proper PPE. All waste generated was containerized in (7) 55-gallon poly drum, and (7) 55-gallon metal drum which was then taken offsite by contractors for proper disposal.

item.title: Report I-2023120054
item.description:
Report I-2023120054

Identified by scraper @ 2024-01-19T15:12:18+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-11-17
  • City: Middletown
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: LARSON BROTHERS INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Upon inspection it was noted that the banding and securement of the batteries was not adequate. Banding was running across the top of battery terminals and only went one way across the ballet rather than overlapping. Metal banding across positive and negative battery terminals caused the battery to heat and ignite in the back of the trailer.
